div.l: Till that he had all the sight seyne
And daunced well he wolde com̄ ageyne
And gadred hym̄ a menye of his sorte
To hoppe and syng and make suche disporte
And there they seten̄ steven̄ for to mete
To pley at the dice in such a strete
For in the toun̄ was no prentise
That fairer can̄ cast a peire of dise
Than Piers coude · and therto he was fre
Of his expens in place of privite
That fande his Master well in his Chaffare
For ofte tyme he fande his Box full bare
For sothe a prentise a Reveloure
That hauntith dyce · Riot and paramoure
His Master shall it in his shoppe a bye
Though he haue no parte of the Mynstralsye
For thefte and Riot they ben̄ conuertible
All can̄ he pley or gitterne and Ribible
Revell and trouthe as in a lowe degre
They ben̄ full wroth all day men̄ may se
This Ioly prentise with his Master stood
Till he was nygh oute of his prentishood
All were he snybbyng bothe erly and late
And somtyme ladde for revell to Newegate
But at the laste · his Master hym be thought
Vppon̄ a day when̄ he his papur sought
Of a proverbe that seith this same worde
Well bettir is roten̄ apull oute of horde
Than̄ that he rote all the remenaunt
So it fareth by a roten̄ Seruaunt
It is well lasse harme to lette hym̄ passe
Then̄ he shende all the servauntis in a place
Therfore his Master made hym̄ acquytaunce
And bade hym̄ go with sorwowe and myschaunce
And thus this Ioly prentise had his leve
Nowe lette hym̄ roiot all nyght or leve
And for there is no thif withoute a louke
That helpith hym̄ to waste and to souke
Of that he bribe can̄ or borowe may
Anōn he sent his bed with his aray
